verses.verse: (Moses Goes to Egypt) So Moses went and returned to (Ex. 2:21; 3:1; 4:18) Jethro his father-in-law, and said to him, “Please let me go and return to my brethren who are in Egypt, and see whether they are still alive.” And Jethro said to Moses, (Gen. 43:23; Judg. 18:6) “Go in peace.”
Now the LORD said to Moses in (Ex. 3:1; 18:1) Midian, “Go, return to (Gen. 46:3, 6) Egypt; for all the men who (Ex. 2:15, 23; Matt. 2:20) sought your life are dead.”

Then Moses (Ex. 18:2-5; Acts 7:29) took his wife and his sons and set them on a donkey, and he returned to the land of Egypt. And Moses took (Ex. 4:17; 17:9; Num. 20:8, 9, 11) the rod of God in his hand.

And the LORD said to Moses, “When you go back to Egypt, see that you do all those (Ex. 3:20; 11:9, 10) wonders before Pharaoh which I have put in your hand. But (Ex. 7:3, 13; 9:12, 35; 10:1, 20, 27; 14:4, 8; Deut. 2:30; Josh. 11:20; 1 Sam. 6:6; Is. 63:17; John 12:40; Rom. 9:18) I will harden his heart, so that he will not let the people go.
Then you shall (Ex. 5:1) say to Pharaoh, ‘Thus says the LORD: (Is. 63:16; 64:8; Hos. 11:1; (Rom. 9:4; 2 Cor. 6:16, 18)) “Israel is My son, (Jer. 31:9; (James 1:18)) My firstborn.
So I say to you, let My son go that he may serve Me. But if you refuse to let him go, indeed (Ex. 11:5; 12:29; Ps. 105:36; 135:8; 136:10) I will kill your son, your firstborn.” ’ ”
And it came to pass on the way, at the (Gen. 42:27) encampment, that the LORD (Ex. 3:18; 5:3; Num. 22:22) met him and sought to (Gen. 17:14) kill him.
Then (Ex. 2:21; 18:2) Zipporah took (Gen. 17:14; Josh. 5:2, 3) a sharp stone and cut off the foreskin of her son and cast it at Moses’ feet, and said, “Surely you are a husband of blood to me!”
So He let him go. Then she said, “You are a husband of blood!”—because of the circumcision.
And the LORD said to Aaron, “Go into the wilderness (Ex. 4:14) to meet Moses.” So he went and met him (Ex. 3:1; 18:5; 24:13) on the mountain of God, and kissed him.
So Moses (Ex. 4:15, 16) told Aaron all the words of the LORD who had sent him, and all the (Ex. 4:8, 9) signs which He had commanded him.
Then Moses and Aaron (Ex. 3:16; 12:21) went and gathered together all the elders of the children of Israel.
(Ex. 4:15, 16) And Aaron spoke all the words which the LORD had spoken to Moses. Then he did the signs in the sight of the people.

So the people (Ex. 3:18; 4:8, 9; 19:9) believed; and when they heard that the LORD had (Gen. 50:24; Ex. 3:16) visited the children of Israel and that He (Ex. 2:25; 3:7) had looked on their affliction, then (Gen. 24:26; Ex. 12:27; 1 Chr. 29:20) they bowed their heads and worshiped.

(First Encounter with Pharaoh) Afterward Moses and Aaron went in and told Pharaoh, “Thus says the LORD God of Israel: ‘Let My people go, that they may hold (Ex. 3:18; 7:16; 10:9) a feast to Me in the wilderness.’ ”
And Pharaoh said, (2 Kin. 18:35; 2 Chr. 32:14; Job 21:15) “Who is the LORD, that I should obey His voice to let Israel go? I do not know the LORD, (Ex. 3:19; 7:14) nor will I let Israel go.”

So they said, (Ex. 3:18; 7:16) “The God of the Hebrews has (Ex. 4:24; Num. 23:3) met with us. Please, let us go three days’ journey into the desert and sacrifice to the LORD our God, lest He fall upon us with (Ex. 9:15) pestilence or with the sword.”
Then the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why do you take the people from their work? Get back to your (Ex. 1:11; 2:11; 6:6) labor.”
And Pharaoh said, “Look, the people of the land are (Ex. 1:7, 9) many now, and you make them rest from their labor!”
So the same day Pharaoh commanded the (Ex. 1:11; 3:7; 5:10, 13, 14) taskmasters of the people and their officers, saying,
“You shall no longer give the people straw to make (Ex. 1:14) brick as before. Let them go and gather straw for themselves.
And you shall lay on them the quota of bricks which they made before. You shall not reduce it. For they are idle; therefore they cry out, saying, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to our God.’
Let more work be laid on the men, that they may labor in it, and let them not regard false words.”
